metadata.name: claustrophobia
metadata.description:
Imagine you are trapped in a dark and small room; you will feel suffocated; Fear of potential suffocation in a limited space; psychologists call it Claustrophobia; the irony is that most of us spend most of our lives in confined spaces - we call home and we feel safe! 
The same psychologists who call fear of a confined spaces chlastrophobia, call "the need for confined space for living" a primary element for feeling safe in life! 
So what is the difference between feeling claustrophobic and safe? The difference is the "way out"... 
Seeing "there is a way out" makes us feel safe in a confined space without feeling claustrophobic. 

 Now, what about our thought limits? Why we feel claustrophobic when we are confined in a space without a clear way out, but we feel ok without seeing a way out of our thoughts and beliefs. Should we be claustrophobic when we think we know it all and right?
